definition.value: The position of a material entity relative to sea-level and closer to earths center
The position of a material entity relative to sea-level and further away from earths center
Properties of events where a portion of material is taken from a population of material which may or may not be at some geographic location
Written procedure for how to sample a material entity from a population of that entity
Equipment that is used in the field in the collection of samples for chemical analysis
The addition of chemical substances to stabilize the concentration/amount of the analyte(s) in a field sample for a long enough time period such that accurate results may be obtained.
Roles that material entities play as part of sampling process

Chemical entity that acts as a stabilizing agent for a sample. As a result of its action, the sample concentration of an analyte chemical entity is kept constant for extended period of time, such that it can be analyzed and an accurate estimate of the concentration of the analyte determined.
Vessel used to store a sample after it has been collected.  Normally made of glass or plastic.  Must be free from labile chemical substances that could potentially contaminate the sample.
A property or characteristic of sample
Information about how a sample was stored, e.g. temperature, pressure, atmosphere, light exposure etc.
Materials used to perform a chemical analysis including solutions, chemicals, glassware, and analytical components (e.g. analytical column, SPE cartridge, etc.)
A name used to identify a sample
A string used to identifiy a subsample
Defined process by which a sample is modified in preparation for chemical analysis in order to minimize sample matrix effects on the analyte concentration
Methods by which physical/chemical processing of samples are performed prior to chemical analysis
The maximum time between sampling and analysis such that the concentration of an determined analyte is deemed accurate, i.e. there has been no degradation of the analyte concentration

Chain of custody is a process that must be followed for evidence to be legally defensible (acceptable to courts and government agencies). It involves these main elements:

* The evidence collector properly identifies the evidence.
* The evidence collector must be a neutral party who has no personal interest in the test results (e.g., a hospital, clinic, or laboratory staff person).
* The evidence collector tamper-proofs and secures evidence at the collection site.
A systematic error in the measure of a signal caused by the presence of concomitants in a sample.

A device or a combination of devices used to carry out an analytical process. The analytical process is all or part of the analytical procedure that encompasses all steps from the introduction of the sample or the test portion to the production of the result. An analytical instrument may carry out single or multiple analytical procedures. In the latter case it may be selective, i.e. designed to carry out any requested combination of procedures within the set, on each specimen.
Process of chemical analysis that is performed using traditional bench glassware physically manipulated by an analyst
Identifier given by the instrument manufacturer that identifies the type of instrument
Unique number to identify a specific instrument of an instrument model given by the instrument manufacturer
Name of the software used to control an instruments operation
Version of the software used to control an instruments operation
Name of the operating system on which the instrument control software runs
Version of the operating system on which the instrument control software runs
A device that is peripheral to an analytical instrument and adds a specific functionality that supports the operation of the analytical instrument
Textual representation of the arrangement or layout of a scientific instrument in enough detail that it allows other scientists to replicate the arrangement.
Numeric values used to characterise the quality of an chemical analysis methodology
Numeric value from a chemometric test peformed on data from a chemical analysis
A numeric value determined from a validation process that allows an estimate of accuracy, or assess reliability over time or across laboratories

Analysis of a sample of a standard reference material or certified reference material to verify the accuracy of chemical analysis procedure.  The data item contains the mean concentration and the confidence interval.

Analysis of a sample spiked with a known amount of analyte.  The result is compared to the analysis portion of the same sample and the different is compared to the amount of analyte added.  If the difference in the results is equivalent ot the amount added then the recovery is deemed 100%.
A chemical substance that is being investigated as to its presence and/or concentration in a sample using a chemical analysis procedure
The maintenance and statement of the quality of a product (data set, etc.) specifically that it meets or exceeds some minimum standard based on known, testable criteria.
The term secondary standard can also be applied to a substance whose active agent contents have been found by comparison against a primary standard.
Reaction of acidic chemical substance with a basic chemical substance to form water and a salt.  The pH of the resulting solution is more 'neutral' (close to pH 7) than each of the reactants alone.

For Brønsted acids the tendency of a compound to act as a hydron (proton) donor. It can be quantitatively expressed by the acid dissociation constant of the compound in water or some other specified medium. For Lewis acids it relates to the association constants of Lewis adducts and π adducts.
A chemical substance that is the pharmacologically active ingredient of a pharmaceutical

Set of data (either measurement or result data) that constitutes a logical grouped entity for the purpsose of deriving additional information (visual, textual, or numeric). For example, calibration data.
Roles that material entities play as part of a chemical analysis procedure
A role of performing a chemical analysis of a sample
Containers, utensils, and apparati that are used in a chemical laboratory and are made of glass
A homogeneous mixture of two chemical substances in a solid.  Commonly one metal dissolved in another.

A group of related (either through structure, chemical reactivity, or usage) chemical substances that can be determined by a specific chemical analysis procedure, e.g. PAH's, PCB's, heavy metals, etc.
Glass apparati that are used in the process of performing chemical analysis, e.g. volumetric flask, volumetric pipet, burette
An instrument or apparatus used in performing chemical analysis procedures
A piece of an instrument with a specific functionality that can be identified as a discrete entity, e.g. electron capture detector or analytical column
A physical separation process used to isolate analyte(s) from the sample matrix prior to analysis
